'Sandalj HraniÄ KosaÄa' (Cyrillic: Ð¡Ð°Ð½Ð´Ð°Ñ Ð¥ÑÐ°Ð½Ð¸Ñ ÐÐ¾ÑÐ°ÑÐ°; 1370 â 15 March 1435)
was a Bosnian medieval noble from the House of KosaÄa. He ruled the
area between Neretva and Drina rivers in Bosnia with the title [[Grand Duke]] of
[[Zahumlje|Hum]] between 1392 and his death in 1435. He was married three times,
but had no children. After his death, he was succeeded by his nephew Stjepan
VukÄiÄ KosaÄa.

As the head of the House of KosaÄa, Sandalj HraniÄ succeeded his uncle
Vlatko VukoviÄ.

, the court of Sandalj HraniÄ where Jelena went to live after she married him]]
When Ladislaus of Naples sold his rights to the kingdom of Dalmatia to the
Republic of Venice and retreated from the Balkans in 1409, many local nobles
allied themselves with the emperor Sigismund and accepted Ostoja as the King of
Bosnia. This seriously weakened the position of Hrvoje whose niece Katarina was
Sandalj's second wife. In such circumstances Sandalj also allied with emperor
Sigismund in mid 1411 and decided to establish closer connections with
Sigismund's important ally Stefan LazareviÄ by marrying his sister
Jelena. In December 1411 he divorced his wife Katarina and married
Jelena at the end of the same year. This
marriage had its important political consequences because HraniÄ, the most
dangerous enemy of BalÅ¡a III, became his stepfather and protector.
With this marriage Sandalj spoiled the relations with Hrvoje but strengthened
traditionally close relations with LazareviÄ family. Jelena went to
live with her husband in Herzegovina and BalÅ¡a remained as the only governor of
Zeta. Although Jelena was ih her forties HraniÄ hoped they would have
children and left a deposit in Dubrovnik dedicated to the child they would
eventually have.

After 1419 Sandalj became the most powerful man in the region of Bosnia and
Herzegovina. After he took part in the conspiracy to kill Pavle RadenoviÄ in
1415, HraniÄ came in conflict with PavloviÄ family. In fighting against them, he
allied with Ottoman Empire. In 1420 Ishak Bey organized unsuccessful campaign in
Bosnia to support Sandalj's struggle against his enemies.

At the beginning of February 1426 a special ceremony was dedicated to Jelena and
Sandalj in Dubrovnik when they attended the feast of Sveti Vlaho (Saint Blaise),
who is the city's patron saint. Sandalj often had conflicts with King
Stephen Tvrtko II of Bosnia, even refusing to attend his wedding to Dorothy
Garai in 1428.

Sandalj died in 1435. He was succeeded by his nephew Stjepan VukÄiÄ KosaÄa who
was a son of Sandalj's brother Vukac.
